description:
Gymnoscopelus braueri, commonly known as Brauer's lanternfish, is a species of lanternfish found in the Southern Ocean. It belongs to the family Myctophidae, which are small, mesopelagic fish that inhabit the intermediate depths of the ocean.

Gymnoscopelus braueri is a small fish, typically reaching a maximum length of around 10 centimeters. It has a fusiform, streamlined body shape that is well-adapted for swimming in the open ocean. The fish is equipped with numerous light-producing photophores, which are specialized organs that can emit bioluminescent light. These photophores are used for various purposes, such as camouflage, communication, and prey attraction.

The distribution of Gymnoscopelus braueri is primarily restricted to the Southern Ocean, where it can be found in waters around Antarctica and the sub-Antarctic islands. It is a mesopelagic species, meaning it primarily inhabits the middle depths of the ocean, typically between 200 and 1,000 meters.

Like other lanternfish, Gymnoscopelus braueri plays an important role in the marine food web, serving as a prey item for larger predatory fish, marine mammals, and seabirds. It is also an important component of the diet of various commercial fish species in the Southern Ocean.
